section.title: Welcome to &PB; &PRODUCT_VERSION;
section.para: &PB; is a secure client hypervisor with management support. &PB; &PRODUCT_VERSION; includes a number of security and isolation enhancements, and robustness improvements. See for more details of security vulnerabilities fixed in this release. Other features of this release are:

listitem.para: Fixed erratic scrollbar when scrolling through long lists of VM icons in &BC;.
SDK fixes, including restoration of missing files and correction of contents listing.
Ability to modify properties of deployed VMs.
Greyed out icon for running VMs marked for deletion.
If &BACKEND; detects that VM disks have been modified by another party, &BACKEND; will restore the disks to the target state.
Various fixes to VM icons in &BC; to prevent flickering and scrolling glitches.
VMs now will only attempt to boot from devices specified in the boot order settings, instead of attempting to boot from disk, optical media and floppy drive respectively as fallback.
SELinux policy change to allow vhd-util to access the VHD key for VMs deployed by &BACKEND;.
Support for disks that are both measured and encrypted.

section.title: What's new in XT 3.1
section.para: XT 3.1 features a number of general reliability and robustness improvements in a number of areas, as well as new XenClient and &BACKEND; functionality. Some of the highlights of this release are listed below:

listitem.para: Windows 8 support as a virtual machine.

Improved Measured Launch configuration experience and robustness: removing the need to use the command-line to set up the product to use TXT and the TPM, as well as broader hardware compatibility and reliability.

API improvements: A number of new features are exposed to service VMs, including the ability to request user attention, provision of a random data source from domain 0, access to the APIs from Windows VMs, and firewall control.

Greater VM and platform configurability from &BACKEND;: prevent access to the local terminal, deliver and boot VMs from ISO images, ability to prevent users from changing VM policy of synchronized VMs.
Non-platform &BACKEND;s, allowing administrators to configure a &BACKEND; to be unable to modify platform settings or upgrade the platform software.

para.emphasis: Improved support for USB devices in Linux VMs.

listitem.para: Service VM deployment via the &BACKEND;: configuring VM properties such as multiple networks and internal firewall rules.

section.para: These features extend the management and isolation improvements introduced in &PB; 3.0.

section.title: Upgrading from a previous version
section.para: This release supports upgrade from the &UPGRADEABLE_PRODUCT_RELEASES; of &PB;. The installation CD provided with this release can be used to upgrade a standalone system. Alternatively, the over-the-air upgrade feature can be used to perform the upgrade on a running system. The user should specify the location of the upgrade repository that is provided as part of the release materials. If the client is being managed by a &BACKEND;, this configuration can be done by the administrator on the &BACKEND;. For more details of upgrading a device via &BACKEND;, please refer to the &BACKEND; Administrator's Guide.

The &BACKEND; can also be upgraded from a previous version. The service should be taken offline temporarily for the procedure (this takes only a small number of minutes to perform). For detailed instructions on performing this upgrade, please refer to the &BACKEND; Administrator Guide.
As with any software upgrade, please be sure to back up any essential data before beginning the upgrade procedure.

entry.para: Revocation of SINIT ACM v51 and v59 - Action Required

Issue: Intel has disclosed a security vulnerability in the SINIT ACM for 2nd and 3rd generation i5 and i7 processors. The vulnerable ACM has been removed from &PB; and a new version of this ACM with the vulnerability fixed is in place in this latest release. While the vulnerable SINIT ACM has been removed from &PB;, &PB; users are strongly advised to revoke the vulnerable SINIT ACM. A description of the vulnerability and directions for revoking the effected SINIT ACM can be found here
https://security-center.intel.com/advisory.aspx?intelid=INTEL-SA-00035&languageid=en-fr.

note.para: Due to the nature of the SINIT ACM revocation, &PB; is no longer able to support the legacy 2nd generation only SINIT ACM. This was included in previous releases to maintain compatibility with Dell 2nd generation system that are not compatible with the new 2nd and 3rd generation combined SINIT ACM. A future BIOS update for Dell 2nd gen i5 and i7 systems may fix this issue.

entry.para: Networking problems in Windows VMs after upgrading tools
Issue: Windows VM wired and/or wireless drivers may not be correctly installed after tools upgrade.

Workaround: The problem is with &PB; Windows tools upgrade rather than fresh install so one workaround is to create a new Windows VM from scratch and install tools in to it. Alternatively, in the affected VM:

step.para: From the Windows Control Panel, open Device Manager.
Identify the device which is not working (Citrix PV Ethernet Adapter for wired networking or Citrix PV Wireless Adapter for wireless networking).
From the Windows Control Panel, open Device Manager.
Right-click the device and choose Update driver software....
Choose Search automatically for updated driver software.
This step may report The best driver software for your device is already installed or Windows encountered a problem installing the driver software for your device.
Right-click the device and choose Uninstall.
If this offers the option to Delete the driver software for this device, leave this option unselected.
Right click any device in device manager and choose Scan for hardware changes.
The device should now be working correctly.

entry.para: USB issues in Windows XP VMs

Issue: The &PB; USB service may fail to start on a Windows XP VM unless certain libraries from Microsoft .NET 3.5 are installed in the VM. To determine whether the service is running, open Task Manager and check whether CitrixUSB.exe appears in the list of processes.
Workaround: Install Microsoft .NET 3.5 in the VM. This is included on the &PV_TOOLS; CD.
USB 3 ports not supported
Issue: USB 3 ports are not supported in this release. These ports can be used to power or charge USB devices, but not for connectivity.
Workaround: None known at the moment.
PXE installation of Debian Squeeze VMs not supported
Issue: Installation of Debian Squeeze on &PB; VMs is not supported due to missing symbols in the sd_mod driver in the Squeeze kernel.
Workaround: Install Debian Squeeze VMs with an installation disk. Alternatively, you can use the GTK PXE Installer.

entry.para: Ubuntu 12.04 VM may fail to suspend when a USB storage device is attached
Issue: An Ubuntu 12.04 VM may fail to suspend if a USB storage device is assigned to the VM.
Workaround: Remove the USB storage device from the VM before suspending the VM.
Intel Trusted Execution Technology (TXT) Does Not Work on Dell Latitude E6420
Workaround: None known at present.
Device Stability Issues with 3D Graphics Passthrough
There are a number of issues that may be experienced when enabling 3D graphics passthrough:

listitem.para: On Ivy Bridge/HD4000 systems, the graphics drivers are not bundled with &PB; as they conflict with older versions of the hardware. These can be downloaded and installed from the Intel website.
Some Lenovo systems may reset the brightness when starting a VM with the Intel drivers. To work around this, try instead installing the OEM driver from the Lenovo website.
&PB; may generally be less stable with 3D Graphics Passthrough enabled. For best use of this feature, minimise the number of other VMs with displays running.

entry.para: Some HP Devices Fail to Resume from Sleep
Issue: On HP 2760p systems, after installation of &PB; and enabling of TXT, the first time the device enters into ACPI State S3 (sleep), &PB; fails to resume.
Workaround: The system has to be manually powered off using the power switch and then restarted. Subsequently, sleep and resume work as expected.
PXE Answerfile Limitation
Issue: The defer="true" attribute on the password tag in the PXE answerfile is not supported in this release.
Using Multiple Monitors with &PB;, Secondary Monitors Are Still Visible When &PB; is Locked

Issue: If you are using &PB; with Secure Authentication with a multi-monitor configuration and have set a timeout for locking the screen (System Settings > Login in the &BRAND_CONSOLE; interface), if the timeout period elapses and the screen locks, secondary monitors are still displayed. You need to make sure any secondary screens are not displaying anything compromising.
Workaround: Assure that any secondary monitors are not displaying anything compromising before locking the &BRAND_CONSOLE; screen.
ATI Graphics VM Hangs when Attempting to Resume from Hibernation
Issue: The Resuming Windows screen hangs when an ATI graphics enabled VM is resumed from hibernation.
Workaround: Do not hibernate a VM that is using ATI graphics.
Graphics Crash on ATI Radeon HD 6570 in HP 8200
Issue: If you are using &PB; with an ATI Radeon HD 6570 in an HP 8200 you may encounter VM crashes.
Workaround: Avoid this combination of graphics card and system.
VMs with multiple vCPUs may be unreliable
Issue: VM crashes have been reported with multiple VCPUs.
Workaround: If you encounter trouble either restore vcpus to 1 or, for Linux VMs, try setting xci-cpuid-signature to false:
entry.screen: xec-vm -n vm_name set vcpus 1 xec-vm -n vm_name set xci-cpuid-signature false

entry.para: Disabling WiFi for a VM has no effect on Linux VMs.

para.emphasis: Issue: WiFi still works on Linux VMs after wireless networking is disabled for that VM, since the WiFi network is treated as a wired network. Similarly, deleting the wired network disables WiFi.

entry.para: Workaround: Delete the second network interface using the UI or: xec-vm -n vmname -c 1 delete
Tools installation on Ubuntu 12.04 may fail due to gdebi-core not being installed
Issue:Installing &PB; tools in an Ubuntu VM may fail with a message asking you to install gdebi-ore.
Workaround: Run: sudo apt-get install gdebi-core then repeat the tool installation.
USB Devices Remain Associated to Windows XP VMs When Put to Sleep Using &BC;
Workaround: Manually disassociate the VM using &BC;.
&HDX; VMs Unstable When Assigned Greater than 3GB of RAM
Workaround: Assign a maximum of 3GB of RAM to a &HDX; VM.
Burning a CD Using Apple iTunes May Fail on Windows 7
Workaround: Please use the Microsoft Windows 7 CD-burning utility.
Mouse Becomes Unresponsive Intermittently on Dell Systems When Using Windows Touchpad Driver
Issue: A conflict between the &PB; emulated generic PS/2 mouse driver and a Dell Touchpad driver causes the mouse to become unresponsive for a brief period on a regular basis.
Workaround: Uninstall the Dell Touchpad driver.
Setting Non-&HDX; VM Display Resolution to 1920x1200 or 1920x1080 Causes Graphics Corruption

Issue: If a laptop display does not natively support 1920x1200 or 1920x1080 resolution, attempting to set the display to such a resolution on a non-&HDX; VM causes graphics corruption. This is a known bug in this release as is should not be possible to set the display to a resolution that is not natively supported.
Workaround: Only set the resolution of a non-&HDX; VM to a natively supported resolution.
Running a Low Resolution &HDX; VM May Interfere With the Displays of Other VMs Using a Higher Resolution
Workaround: Raise the screen resolution setting of the HDX VM.
Disconnection of External Display Does Not Always Trigger Screen Adjustment
Issue: If an external monitor has been attached when a PVM is in use and then it is disconnected with an SVM in use, the screen does not adjust.
Workaround: Switch back to the PVM to update the configuration.
Black Screen and Unresponsive System When Attempting to Update Graphics Drivers
Issue: Attempting to update the graphics drivers on a &HDX;-enabled VM using the Device Manager Update Driver Software function can cause &PB; to hang, requiring a reboot.
Workaround: Do not use the Update Driver Software function to upgrade graphics drivers.
Installing an Updated Webcam Driver Available from Windows Update for the Internal Webcam May Cause it to Stop Working on Some Laptop Models
Workaround: In Device Manager, right click on the effected webcam device and select Properties. Select the Driver tab, and click Roll Back Driver.
Unplugging a USB Audio Device While In Use on an XP VM Can Cause the VM to Hang
Issue: Unplugging a USB audio device, such as a set of USB headphones while it is actively in use can cause an XP VM to hang.
Workaround: Ensure that the USB audio device is not currently is use (for example, currently playing music) and unplug the device using the standard XP mechanism.
Windows Safe Mode Prevents &HDX; VM Switching
Issue: Booting a &HDX; enabled VM into Windows Safe Mode prevents the &PB; Switcher Bar from loading and also switching between VMs using the Ctrl hotkeys.
Workaround: Reboot the VM, exiting Safe Mode.
External Monitor Blank When Attached
Issue: When a &HDX; VM is running and you plug an external monitor into your device when the &HDX; VM is not currently on screen, the screen remains blank.
Workaround: Always switch to the &HDX; VM, if running, before plugging in an external monitor.
Unable to Install VMs from External USB Optical Media Device If Internal Device is Present
Issue: VMs on a laptop with an internal optical media drive cannot boot from an external optical media drive.

procedure.title: To Recover from a Full Disk

step.para: Reboot the &PB; host.
While the &PB; boot screen is displayed, press Esc.
Boot into the console access option.
When a console is available, log in as root.
Delete the file /storage/xc_reserved:
This will free up sufficient disk space to allow you to boot into &PB; and backup your VMs.
